subject: GPC Initial Concept Approval Request #32 (Educational strategies for understanding: How Diverse Are We)
html:
The abovereferenced project has been submitted for Concept Approval. The proposal will be reviewed at the next GPC meeting. You may review the proposal here.

Developers comments:

We propose a 5-year research plan to develop programming around visitor interests about human variability and develop affective strategies for informal educators. Our initial aim is to begin with planning and development building off findings from previous formative evaluation that when presented with multiple specimens of the same organ, such as 2 brains, multiple uteri or several stomachs, visitors quickly self-recognized and called out/questioned phenotypic variability and quickly began developing their own questions about human variability at the genetic level. The other noticeable theme with real human specimens was that the spectrum of visitor emotions became immediately visible. This made us realize the need to provide informal educators with affective teaching strategies in striving for learning equity and in teaching all, not just those who are already engaged. Aim 1: provide information to the public and science cultural institutions that will lead to a better understanding of audiences specific interests levels of understanding of human variability and biomedical research, and gaps in knowledge concerning the connections between human variability and human health. Aim 2. Provide the general public, students, and teachers with engaging opportunities to interact with experts in the field learn and about this critical topic in MOSs exhibit halls to deepen their understanding through resources that extend beyond MOSs walls. Aim 3. Contribute critical insights about the design of learning experiences and resources effective in engaging and educating diverse audiences about the relevance of human variability to human well-being and giving them the tools to increase their understanding of this topic. Aim 3 will inform aims 1 and 2 and be used to develop materials based on our findings for middle school and high school teachers that will share out strategies. Aim 4. Work with teachers to develop and translate the above strategies for affective teaching that support teacher needs in striving for learning for equity and in teaching all, not just those who are already engaged in STEM, and already participating.

The Hub

This is the request you nicknamed "Raye Choi Welcome Represenative". You'll be notified again when the work for this request has been completed, but you can contact the admin with any issues related thereto.

The Hub

subject: Network Access Request #1506: approved
html:
As needed, review the request's details and contact Amy Germaine. When the work for this request has been completed, please update the request status.

The Hub

subject: GPC Initial Concept Approval Request #32 (Educational strategies for understanding: How Diverse Are We)
html:
The abovereferenced project has been submitted for Concept Approval. The proposal will be reviewed at the next GPC meeting. You may review the proposal here.

Developers comments:

We propose a 5-year research plan to develop programming around visitor interests about human variability and develop affective strategies for informal educators. Our initial aim is to begin with planning and development building off findings from previous formative evaluation that when presented with multiple specimens of the same organ, such as 2 brains, multiple uteri or several stomachs, visitors quickly self-recognized and called out/questioned phenotypic variability and quickly began developing their own questions about human variability at the genetic level. The other noticeable theme with real human specimens was that the spectrum of visitor emotions became immediately visible. This made us realize the need to provide informal educators with affective teaching strategies in striving for learning equity and in teaching all, not just those who are already engaged. Aim 1: provide information to the public and science cultural institutions that will lead to a better understanding of audiences specific interests levels of understanding of human variability and biomedical research, and gaps in knowledge concerning the connections between human variability and human health. Aim 2. Provide the general public, students, and teachers with engaging opportunities to interact with experts in the field learn and about this critical topic in MOSs exhibit halls to deepen their understanding through resources that extend beyond MOSs walls. Aim 3. Contribute critical insights about the design of learning experiences and resources effective in engaging and educating diverse audiences about the relevance of human variability to human well-being and giving them the tools to increase their understanding of this topic. Aim 3 will inform aims 1 and 2 and be used to develop materials based on our findings for middle school and high school teachers that will share out strategies. Aim 4. Work with teachers to develop and translate the above strategies for affective teaching that support teacher needs in striving for learning for equity and in teaching all, not just those who are already engaged in STEM, and already participating.

The Hub

subject: GPC Initial Concept Approval Request #38 (STIx Science Communication Coaching)
html:
The abovereferenced project has been submitted for Concept Approval. The proposal will be reviewed at the next GPC meeting. You may review the proposal here.

Developers comments:

I met Taeyjuana Lyons at the February AAAS meeting, and she contacted me late last week to ask if I would submit a plan and a budget this week for enhancing the quality of sci-comm presentations at DOD's annual STIx conference in September, to include in ByteCubed's proposal to DOD. I have sent her the proposed plan, and am waiting for approval before attaching a budget to it.

The Hub
